Field Detail

UI

public BowdoinSoccer.GUI UI
Initially I had these tucked away as private variables, but since the players can't access the world, I can make these public to simpilfy communication between things like the GUI and the ball.

Constructor Detail

World

public World()
Default constructor which creates the world, GUI, and other associated classes.

Method Detail

Go

public final void Go()
Goes into an infinite loop which is broken when System.exit() is called by the closing window. Once the teams are created, there's nothing left for the main thread to do - the players will make their own requests from their individual threads.

LoadTeam

public final boolean LoadTeam(java.lang.String filename,
                              int Side)
This loads a team from the filename it is passed. Do not give it an extension on the filename. The extension ".class" is appended somewhere deep in the bowels of Sun's code. And no, I didn't see that fact documented anywhere either.

Parameters:
filename - The class name of the team to be loaded
Side - Which side of the field it will play on
Returns:
boolean Did it work?

GetTeamID

public final int GetTeamID(BowdoinSoccer.Player Unknown)
Returns either World.EAST or World.WEST depending on which team the player is on. Returns -1 on error.

Parameters:
Unknown - The player we're checking on
Returns:
int The player's team (EAST or WEST)

Look

public final int Look(BowdoinSoccer.Player CuriousGeorge,
                      int Direction)
Returns information about any of the eight squares around the player. It returns OPPONENT, BALL, EMPTY, TEAMMATE, or BOUNDARY. It takes N, NE, E, etc.

Parameters:
CuriousGeorge - The player doing the looking
Direction - The direction they are looking
Returns:
int What they see

GetBallDirection

public final int GetBallDirection(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client)
Returns the direction to the ball.

Parameters:
Client - The player doing the checking.
Returns:
int The direction of the ball from the player's viewpoint.

GetReverseDirection

public final int GetReverseDirection(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client)
Returns the direction of the Player from the point of view of the ball.

Parameters:
Client - The player doing the checking.
Returns:
int The direction of the player from the ball.

GetBallDistance

public final int GetBallDistance(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client)
Gets the distance of the specified player to the ball.

Parameters:
Client - The player in question
Returns:
int How far away they are from the ball.

GetOpponentDirection

public final int GetOpponentDirection(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client,
                                      int nth)
This method returns the direction of the calling player to the nth closest opponent.

Parameters:
Client - The player doing the checking
nth - Which opposing player they're looking for
Returns:
int The direction of that player.

GetCorrectedPlayerLocation

public final java.awt.Point GetCorrectedPlayerLocation(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client)
This allows players to determine where they are. Coordinates are zero based with (0, 0) in the upper left hand corner of the field. The field extends World.XSQUARES to the east and World.YSQUARES to the south. The bottom right corner is: (XSQUARES - 1, YSQUARES - 1) 'cuz it's a zero based coordinate system.

Parameters:
Client - The player whose location we are getting
Returns:
Point The X,Y coordinates of that player

GetPlayerLocation

public final java.awt.Point GetPlayerLocation(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client)
This returns the player's true location on the field. It is not corrected for side...

Parameters:
Client - The player whose location we are getting
Returns:
Point Their X, Y location (will have to be corrected for WEST)

GetOpponentDistance

public final int GetOpponentDistance(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client,
                                     int nth)
Returns the distance of the nth closest player to the client. The original implementation gave players the ability to determine the distance to the closest opponent, the next closest opponent, and so forth. I'd rather give them the distance to player one, player two, etc, just because it makes my life easier, but they'd probably just end up seeing who was closest anyway... So I left it alone; if you pass it 1, it will return the closest. If you pass it 4, it will return the distance to the furthest.

Parameters:
Client - The player doing the checking
nth - Which opponent they are interested in
Returns:
int The distance of that opponent

BallAction

public final boolean BallAction(int Action)
Tries to do something with the ball and checks if it is legal. This is what the ball calls to query the world to see if a given move is valid.

Parameters:
Action - What the ball is doing
Returns:
boolean Is it legal?

GoalScored

public final void GoalScored(int direction)
A goal has been scored, notify the teams and the scoreboard. The ball calls this function to let the world know it's in a goal.

Parameters:
direction - Which side scored the goal.

PlayerAction

public final boolean PlayerAction(BowdoinSoccer.Player Client,
                                  int Action)
This function allows the players to move or kick the ball. Valid arguements are: N, NE, E, SE, S, SW, W, NW, KICK, BALL (move toward ball). The rate at which players can call this function is limited by a blocking thread - don't expect the function to return immediatly.

Parameters:
Client - The player trying to do something
Action - What it is that they want to do
Returns:
boolean Did it work?

WindowClosing

public void WindowClosing()
Reacts to the user closing the main window. Called by GUI when the window is closing - let's us notify the teams that they're about to go bye-bye

GetTeam

public final BowdoinSoccer.Team GetTeam(BowdoinSoccer.Player target)
Returns the team that a given player is on.

Parameters:
target - The player who wants to know.
Returns:
Team Their team.

GetSquareContents

public final int GetSquareContents(java.awt.Point Target)
Returns the contents of a square in the world. It returns BOUNDARY, BALL, EASTPLAYER, WESTPLAYER, or EMPTY. Look() needs to turn EASTPLAYER and WESTPLAYER into TEAMMATE and OPPONENT depending on the caller.

Parameters:
Target - The square we want to know about.
Returns:
int The square's contents.

Timeout

public final void Timeout()
When the game is at an impass we restart.

SetCycles

public void SetCycles(int c)
Track how long the point has been going.

Parameters:
c - The number of cycles

GetCycles

public int GetCycles()
Returns the number of cycles that have gone on.

Returns:
int the number of cycles.

LittleTimeout

public final void LittleTimeout()
When the players wedge the ball between them, we sometimes give it a nudge.
